etymologies: Old English tūcian ‘to punish, ill-treat’: of West Germanic origin; related to tug. Influenced in Middle English by Middle Dutch tucken ‘pull sharply’

definitions: push, fold, or turn (the edges or ends of something, especially a garment or bedclothes) so as to hide them or hold them in place

examples.text: he tucked his shirt into his trousers

notes.text: with object and usually with adverbial of place

shortDefinitions: push, fold, or turn so as to hide or secure them

definitions: draw (something, especially part of one's body) together into a small space

examples.text: she tucked her legs under her

definitions: put (something) away in a specified place or way so as to be hidden, safe, comfortable, or tidy

examples.text: the colonel was coming toward her, his gun tucked under his arm
she tucked her arm into his

shortDefinitions: put or keep something in hidden or tidy place

definitions: make a flattened, stitched fold in (a garment or material), typically so as to shorten or tighten it, or for decoration

examples.text: the suit was pinned and tucked all over

shortDefinitions: make flattened, stitched fold in garment or material

definitions: a flattened, stitched fold in a garment or material, typically one of several parallel folds put in a garment for shortening, tightening, or decoration

examples.text: a dress with tucks along the bodice

shortDefinitions: flattened, stitched fold in garment or material

definitions: a surgical operation to reduce surplus flesh or fat
shortDefinitions: surgical operation to reduce surplus flesh

definitions: food, typically cakes and candy, eaten by children at school as a snack
shortDefinitions: food eaten by children at school as snack

definitions: (in diving, gymnastics, downhill skiing, etc.) a position with the knees bent and held close to the chest, often with the hands clasped around the shins

examples.text: Lenzi nailed a reverse 3–1/2 somersault tuck on his final dive

shortDefinitions: position with knees bent and held close to chest
